awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CNS Core: Medium: FROOT: Future-Proof, Trustworthy Telemetry on Heterogeneous Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
With the growth of the Internet and its importance in supporting the US economy, business, health, education and other services, it is critical to ensure both high performance and high availability of the networks underlying it.  Increasingly, such networks include a heterogeneous set of network switches and other devices which must be monitored and controlled in a coordinated manner.  Emerging networked applications, such as cloud gaming or cloud streamed augmented reality, are expected to further stress both control systems and network monitoring by requiring real-time response to rapid changes in traffic workloads. This project aims to address the needs of future network control by enabling a network telemetry infrastructure that can provide timely, accurate, and trusted information about ongoing activities in the network


This project proposes FROOT, a future-proof, trustworthy telemetry infrastructure for networks of heterogeneous programmable devices (e.g., programmable switch, SmartNIC, CPU, and DPU). The project takes an interdisciplinary approach spanning algorithms, systems, and security to inform the design and implementation of next generation telemetry systems through the following: (1) universal sketch-based algorithmic design and implementation for current and new measurement tasks and network devices; (2) novel network-wide resource optimization for handling network dynamics; and (3) trustworthy sketch deployment into heterogeneous devices to obtain critical telemetry information. The researchers also plan to deploy their network telemetry system at Mass Open Cloud testbed, an open public cloud project led by Boston University and other institutions in Massachusetts.  The project will result in the development of open-source tools, algorithms, and prototype implementations that will reduce the time to deploy sketch-based telemetry in real-world scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the growth of the Internet and its importance in supporting the US economy, business, health, education, and other services, it is critical to ensure both high performance and high availability of the networks underlying it. Increasingly, such networks include a heterogeneous set of network devices that must be monitored and controlled in a coordinated manner. Emerging networked applications, such as critical cloud services or cloud-streamed augmented reality, are expected to further stress both control systems and network monitoring by requiring real-time response to rapid changes in network traffic. This project aims to address the needs of future network control by enabling a network telemetry infrastructure that can provide timely, accurate, and trusted information about ongoing activities in the network.

This project challenges the status quo by developing a network-wide telemetry framework for networks that contain the latest innovations in network programmable devices, such as programmable switches, program network interface cards, and data processing units. The Future-pROOf,Trustworthy telemetry (FROOT) system is designed to provide accurate, trustworthy, and real-time measurements for a broad range of current and possibly unforeseen applications across several network domains, including Internet service providers and cloud environments. In particular, realizing the FROOT vision required addressing several research challenges in this project:

  • Telemetry algorithm design and implementation: Telemetry algorithms should be adaptable to unforeseen network issues, such as attacks or performance anomalies. These algorithms need to be efficiently implemented across diverse platforms to enable real-time, accurate measurement. The collaborative research in the project has resulted in efficient and scalable algorithms and their implementations, such as OctoSketch for high-performance monitoring on individual servers and SketchLib for optimized algorithm implementation on network devices.

  • Network-wide resource management: Efficient deployment of telemetry primitives requires intelligent resource allocation to optimize usage and minimize latency. Given the heterogeneity of network hardware architectures, effective placement strategies must balance performance and resilience, ensuring adaptability to device failures and dynamic network conditions. The project developed HeteroSketch, a network-wide telemetry coordination framework that optimally places monitoring tasks across up to 40K heterogeneous devices, balancing efficiency and accuracy.

  • Trustworthy deployment and query: When telemetry capabilities are deployed to the devices in the network, the system must guarantee that the measured results truthfully reflect the underlying network traffic and operators should be able to verify the correctness of the results and use them for their critical services. The project advanced the security of such network telemetry infrastructure with TrustSketch, a trusted execution environment-based system that protects measurement integrity against potential cyberattacks. 

These innovations have been validated and evaluated through peer-reviewed publications and real-world collaborations with industrial partners in the US. Beyond research, the FROOT project has supported education and workforce development efforts by integrating related network research topics into university courses, mentoring undergraduate student projects, and releasing open-source tools for widespread adoption. Our work contributes to autonomous network management, cloud security, and network performance, with future efforts focused on deploying telemetry solutions at scale and collaborating with open-source communities. These contributions ensure that FROOT’s impact continues beyond the NSF funding period, shaping the future of, intelligent, and trustworthy network monitoring. More details are available at the Project Website: https://zaoxing.github.io/projects/frootsecure.
